text:
With e.g.

  <rect id="t" width="100" height="100" fill="#fff"  />

ECMAScript such as

  document
    .getElementById("t")
    .getPresentationAttribute("fill")
    .RGBColor

returns the css::RGBColor,

  document
    .getElementById("t")
    .getPresentationAttribute("fill")
    .rgbColor

returns null. Per http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/ecmascript-binding.html it should 
be the other way round.
creator: bjoern@hoehrmann.de

text: Well spotted.  I'll commit the fix later today or tomorrow.
creator: cam@apache.org

text:
Be careful on this.  The issue is the mapping of the IDL into Java.
It is a little unclear to me if 'rgbColor' should map to 
'getRgbColor' or 'getRGBColor'.  The second issue is how Rhino
reflects this method into emcaScript.

Please don't do anything with this until after the release.
creator: deweese@apache.org
cam@apache.org
text:
I'm reasonably sure that Rhino will expose a property called 'rgbColor' if there
exists a method called 'getRgbColor'.  Since the Java binding specifies a method
called 'getRGBColor', both methods will need to be in there.  (The 'getRGBColor'
method will still expose an attribute called 'RGBColor', but extra properties
like this get exposed all the time with methods called (get* and set*).)

But I'll leave it until after the release.

creator: deweese@apache.org
text:
Hmm, I thought you might rename the method.  If you are
going to add it is probably safe for the release.
I wanted to avoid the possiblity that we would have to
'wish wash' on the function name.

Cameron, if you want to do this go ahead.

creator: cam@apache.org
text:
Fix is in CVS now, for 'rgbColor' and 'iccColor'.  Leaving any other commits
until after the release. :)
